subject: Scary Stuff
event:
I know that there are a lot of people out there who opposed health care reform, for a variety of reasons (witness the 400 + responses to my health care post)... but the stuff that's going on right now across the country is scary.  Congressmen who voted for the bill are receiving anyonymous death threats to them and their families, bricks are being thrown through their offices, right wing blogs are publishing their home addresses and urging people to "visit" them.  And more... it's all over the news, I won't go into details here.

However you feel about the new health care reforms, I hope that all of you reading this -- be you Democrats, Republicans, Libertarians, liberals, conservatives, socialists, anarchists, Greens, Reds, Blues, tea baggers, latte drinkers, or what you -- will join with me in totally condemning this behavior and all those who engage in it.

And shame, shame, shame on the "respectable" leaders who are encouraging and excusing this sort of stuff, or trying to shrug it off with feeble half-hearted condemnations.

I hope the people throwing bricks and making death threats will all be found, arrested, tried, and punished.  This kind of crap has no place in our political process.  

People who express their political opinions by throwing bricks through windows are no better than nazis.  Google "Kristallnacht" for a scary sense of deja vu.

Surely THIS is something that all decent people, be they right or left, can agree on.

comments.article: I think its shameful behavior and disgusting neither side no matter whatever your opinion should do these disgusting acts. Shame on the republicans and I can't believe people are actually contemplating voting for these guys. They are going to reward these people for encouraging violence?
comments.subject: I agree

comments.upictitle: If my username doesn't give you a clue, Fuck off: pic#0
comments.article: First off, this brutish behavior is completely reprehensible and I'm sure 95 percent of Americans would agree with me that this is not the way any civil person should behave. But while I'm an independent, I do not believe it is fair to blame conservatives as a general proposition. Its true the Republican party has been hijacked by some radical elites who use fear and simple good vs. evil rhetoric to further their own sorry careers (Sarah Palin, John Boehner, etc.). Republican legislators have also received threats, and many Republicans at the state level are instead going about civil ways of trying to fight against a law they don't believe in, such as lawsuits and rallying for voter support in the upcoming election. While I agree we should collectively condemn these unfortunate radical attacks, this country has not descended into barbaric chaos, and will in the end remain a democracy where free ideas are allowed to thrive.
comments.subject: Re: I agree

comments.article:
What the hell is happening over there man? I grew up on the West Coast of Scotland, way back in the 1970's and America was a beacon of freedom, truth, and Marvel comics. I first visited the States in the 90's, and it was everything I'd dreamed it would be - big, scary, and with a heart bigger than the world.
I hope, I really hope, and I pray (and I'm not given to praying) that you come through this dark time, because we need our friends back.

As an American, I beg you to stay over in Scotland for your own good.  America is heading down the sewer really fast.  I fear for my children's future here.  It will be full of fear, hatred, religious extremists, biggotry, etc.  I honestly believe the terrorists won on 9/11.  We haven't been the same since and things are getting worse every year.

comments.upictitle: They Call Me Roxy: Actres- Keira bored
comments.article: There's absolutely no excuse for it, and it's embarrassing quite frankly that so many Americans would stoop to such a level.

Being from Canada, I am at a complete loss as to what to make of this...

This kind of behavior is regarded as terrorism in the rest of the G8. And being about giving health care to more than 30 million people who have a hard time getting it, this is no cause for such madness!! If it would be about something « seriously » harmful to the people, I would be closer to understanding such « acts ». But being in reaction to the effort to help those in need and to bring some respite to those who don’t fit into your health insurance system... It is not understandable to me :¬(
comments.subject: I feel your pain...

comments.article: Well said!
I'll gladly second this.  I honestly can't believe that it has come to this.  It's sad and frightening.  I sincerely hope that common sense and civility comes to the fore and overcomes this madness.
Sounds like the kinds of things the anti-choicers were doing that got Dr. Tiller killed.  You never hear about liberals responding with this kind of malice and hatred....

I'm a liberal myself and am also appalled by this behavior but I find a problem with this part of your post. "You never hear about liberals responding with this kind of malice and hatred"

That's the same generalization that these conservatives make all the time. Do you remember when W Bush was president? He had death threats all over the country.
comments.subject: not so fast

comments.upictitle: The Knight in Shining Skull T-shirt: pic#106375917
comments.article: I'm with you. The fact that political leaders are excusing it is extremely upsetting.

Some people don't realize just how powerful their vote is. You can throw all the bricks you want but the only REAL way to make an impact is to vote or run for office yourself.

If for some reason after voting you still find yourself in the minority; it may be time to look at your views. America is not an extreme country and will never be. Find some common ground with the masses and pick and choose your issues.

Surely THIS is something that all decent people, be they right or left, can agree on.

Sadly, I doubt that highly. Well, strike that. Regular, normal, mostly sane people? Yes, they should all agree.

The people perpetrating and condoning these acts however believe Obama/the Democratic Party to be equal in evil to the Nazi's. Some have even used "King George" rhetoric, implying (to me) that they think it's okay to revolt against this administration. If they have it in their heads that the government is bad enough that a revolution is in order... good luck convincing them that they are working against the greater good. :(

gldd and odie, you are talking about it as if it were an entire party.  It is a small minority just like those who commit Pro-Choice violence or other crimes against conservatives.  And you don't have to search hard on the net to find those.  Ironic how the press doesn't talk about them much?  Or the GOP leaders who have condemned this.  It is not a partisan issue so please don't make it one.  It effects all of us and we are all responsible for it by own intolerance of one another.
comments.subject: Violence

comments.article:
Beck is on the record for begging his viewers not to stoop to violence or threats. He did a whole show this week about how that's what his opponents WANT them to do, and begged them not to give them the satisfaction.
Ironic, that as I'm typing this, your picture has a gun pointed right at my face. Good thing I'm not assuming this is a personal threat, huh?
comments.subject: Beck Denounces Violence

comments.article:
I find it extremely difficult to grasp the concept of anyone not wanting health-care for everyone - regardless of their political agenda. This type of behaviour confounds me even more. I simply don't understand it.
Here's to hoping those committing these acts get the punishment they so richly deserve. It's just plain not good enough.
It's that we know the government is unable to fund and execute what they're setting out to do.  I believe the unintended consequences of this bill will lead to more suffering, not less.
comments.subject: It's not that we don't want health care for everyone.
Re: It's not that we don't want health care for everyone.

comments.article:
It's nothing short of terrorism, what's going on.

I agree with you totally, and I think democracy in America is in a sad state.

While I am at total disagreement with you in your views on the health care debate I must admit that I am troubled by the lack of civility in politics in our country.  This seems to be at every level of government and all parties seem to be equally at fault.  Years from now we may look back and say that the Dems were right or the Repubs were right but what we will definitely say is why does the debate have to be ugly.  I can respect the fact that other people have differing views from me and isnt that what really makes our country great.  I just dont get it anymore.
comments.subject: Well said

comments.article: Personally I think we're a long way from Kristallnacht.  It's pretty disconcerting though, I won't argue with that.  Hopefully after a week or so people will cool off and go back to posting angrily on the internet.

you are willing to denounce this on both sides, I agree. 

http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/03/2<wbr />5/rep-cantors-richmond-campaign-office-s<wbr />hot-overnight/

I really never got how either side can use this as a reason not to vote for a political party,  there are kooks on both sides.

As long as the elected leaders don't condone these actions or instigate them then there is no reason to 'punish' them by not voting for them.  They really can't stop fools from acting like fools...
comments.subject: As long as...

comments.article:
As long as...
you are willing to denounce this on both sides, I agree. http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/03/25/rep-cantors-richmond-campaign-office-shot-overnight/

I'm a little confused by this link following the mention of "both sides" - just because some Republicans are the victims of this escalating violence and threats from extremists doesn't mean that they're being targeted by Democrats! It's a lot more likely that it's being caused by the same extremists who are targeting Democrats because of their unhappiness with legislative decisions.

As long as the elected leaders don't condone these actions or instigate them

Unfortunately, that is not the case: http://thinkprogress.org/2010/03/21/nunes-tea-part/
comments.subject: Re: As long as...

comments.article:
This kind of crap has no place in our political process society.

Corrected.

Such things are really saddening D: Where is Democraty going, if people have death threats every time they make something that doesn't please someone?

I feel for them, and hope that Democraty will still win.

To be honest, this does not surprise me in the least.  We live in the most violent, fearful, and paranoid "civilized" society in the world.  I would love to move out of here and become a citizen of Canada, Australia, New Zealand, France, etc.  Unfortunately, I can't do such a thing so I will just keep dreaming.  America makes Westeros look like Disney Land.
Agreed in all particulars.

Yeah, the actions of the far right wing have been very disappointing lately. They should be embarrassed.

I hadn't heard of Kristallnacht before, pretty interesting. But c'mon George, don't compare this to that. I don't think this is going to lead to genocide.

Neither did the decent people (there were many millions of them) of the Weimar Republic.

I hope you're right, of course... you probably are... but the symbolism of broken glass is disturbing to anyone who knows his history.

comments.subject: the rifle sights citation site in question-

comments.article:
I just heard about this too, it's pretty freakin' unbelievable. This behavior belongs back in the days of witch trials... BEFORE that even!

I keep asking myself, is this really how the current opposition to our government behaves? Is this violence typical of the neo-conservatives of today? Maybe it's just whoever's in opposition, and the left-wingers were maybe this violent during the Bush years, but we're too blind to see it... but I honestly doubt it, as much as I hate to be that judgemental against a particular group of people.

First off, I'm Canadian. We look at your politics as extremely polarized, adolescent and impolite, for the most part.

I think that part of the problem in America with such acts being countenanced by some is a consequence of the Cold War.

America, rightly or wrongly, was the arsenal of democracy in the Cold War. It made great sacrifices and became one the two Great Poles around which all others in the world revolved. America deserves thanks for most of its efforts in the Cold War -- though not for all of those efforts.

During that struggle, to re-enforce national resolve, America adopted extreme ideological views towards "socialism" and "communism" that no other industrial democracy ever took. These extreme views enabled America to persevere in the Cold War but they came at a great political cost. America emerged from the Cold War a half-centry later as the most ideological of all industrial democracies in the world.

The world isn't black and white and absolutist views rarely describe the truth of economic and social policies. However, when so many Americans view the world through such a black and white lens of good and evil; right and wrong, it makes it easy to legitimize a resort to violence as a solution to an "evil" problem.

Add that to a simplisitic and romanticized view of the Fathers of the Revolution deliberately fostered in all Americans in grade school civics, combine that with a bit of anti-intellectual Tea Party nonsense -- and add a touch of Old South lynch mob mentality - and you have all it takes to motivate people in a democracy to lob bricks and molotovs through the office windows of elected officials.
comments.subject: Absolute Views lead to Extremism

comments.article:
*sigh* Yes.

My people, they are nuts. =(

comments.article:
I completely agree. I'm a liberal person but I know a lot of very kind, respectable conversatives. So when I say the following please understand that I intend it for a small minority of conservatives.

These right-wing, nut jobs need to stop listening to inflammatory political talk show personalities and Christian extremist preachers and start to think for themselves. I listen to both of these types of sources on occasion just to see what they are saying and it makes all fo this behavior make sense. They all band togeather to tell their audiences their doom and gloom rhetoric to try to advance their own cause. In the process they have convinced those audiences that Obama is somehow both a socialist and a Fascist (which doesn't make any damned sense at all) and that there is a secret liberal movement trying to take over our country.

Of course these people are responding with radical behavior. They placed their trust in people who told scared them into beleiving that radical behavior is the only solution. I don't think this was the agenda, I believe these media personalities created a monster that they have now lost control over. However, the truly offensive part is that even as things escalate to violence those same people refuse to condemn or fight againat the actions of the monster they unleashed.

I'm not from USA (i'm european) and i dont't really understand all the fuss, sure, public health care is expensive, but it's too a right, i mean, if there's something that can be done for an ill person it HAS to be done, waste a live or just a healthy live when you could have done something seems like something insane, at least for me. I don't know, you can think wathever you want of course, but i asure you i live in a country with public health care and it's not something that voters me, and it's there when you need it.

Of course these people are responding with radical behavior. They placed their trust in people who told scared them into believing that radical behavior is the only solution. I don't think this was the agenda, I believe these media personalities created a monster that they have now lost control over. However, the truly offensive part is that even as things escalate to violence those same people refuse to condemn or fight against the actions of the monster they unleashed.
